statements.name: PROC MULTTEST
statements.description: The MULTTEST procedure addresses the multiple testing problem. This problem arises when you perform many hypothesis tests on the same data set. Carrying out multiple tests is often reasonable because of the cost of obtaining data, the discovery of new aspects of the data, and the many alternative statistical methods.

arguments.name: ADAPTIVEFDR
arguments.description: Requests adjusted p-values by using the Benjamini and Hochberg (2000) adaptive linear step-up method.

arguments.name: ADAPTIVEHOCHBERG
arguments.description: Requests adjusted p-values by using the Hochberg and Benjamini (1990) adaptive step-up Bonferroni method.

arguments.name: ADAPTIVEHOLM
arguments.description: Requests adjusted p-values by using the Hochberg and Benjamini (1990) adaptive step-down Bonferroni method.

arguments.name: BONFERRONI
arguments.description: Specifies that the Bonferroni adjustments (number of tests x p-value) be computed for each test.

arguments.name: BOOTSTRAP
arguments.description: Specifies that the p-values be adjusted by using the bootstrap method to resample vectors (Westfall and Young; 1993).

arguments.name: CENTER
arguments.description: Requests that continuous variables be mean-centered prior to resampling. The default action is to mean-center for bootstrap resampling and not to mean-center for permutation resampling.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: Names the input SAS data set to be used by PROC MULTTEST.

arguments.name: DEPENDENTFDR
arguments.description: Requests adjusted p-values by using the method of Benjamini and Yekateuli (2001).

arguments.name: EPSILON=
arguments.description: Specifies the amount by which two p-values must differ to be declared unequal. The value number must be between 0 and 1; the default value is 1000 times the machine epsilon, which is approximately 1E–12.

arguments.name: FDRBOOT
arguments.description: A bootstrap-resampling false discovery rate controlling method due to Yekateuli and Benjamini (1999).

arguments.name: FDRPERM
arguments.description: A permutation-resampling false discovery rate controlling method due to Yekateuli and Benjamini (1999).

arguments.name: FDR
arguments.description: Requests adjusted p-values by using the linear step-up method of Benjamini and Hochberg (1995).

arguments.name: FISHER_C
arguments.description: Requests adjusted p-values by using Fisher’s combination method.

arguments.name: HOCHBERG
arguments.description: Requests adjusted p-values by using the step-up Bonferroni method due to Hochberg (1988).

arguments.name: HOLM
arguments.description: Is an alias for the STEPBON adjustment

arguments.name: HOMMEL
arguments.description: Requests adjusted p-values by using the method of Hommel (1988).

arguments.name: INPVALUES=
arguments.description: Names an input SAS data set that includes a variable containing raw p-values. The pvalue-name enables you to specify the name of the p-value column from your data set. By default, pvalue-name=’raw_p’.

arguments.name: NOCENTER
arguments.description: Requests that continuous variables not be mean-centered prior to resampling. The default action is to mean-center for bootstrap resampling and not to mean-center for permutation resampling.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: Suppresses the normal display of results.

arguments.name: NOPVALUE
arguments.description: Suppresses the display of the "p-Values" table of raw and adjusted p-values. This option is most useful when you are adjusting many tests and need to create only an OUT= data set or display graphics.

arguments.name: NOTABLES
arguments.description: Suppresses display of the "Discrete Variable Tabulations" and "Continuous Variable Tabulations" tables.

arguments.name: NOZEROS
arguments.description: Suppresses display of tables having zero occurrences for all CLASS levels.

arguments.name: NSAMPLE=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of resamples for use with the resampling methods. The value number must be a positive integer; by default, 20,000 resamples are used.

arguments.name: NTRUENULL=
arguments.description: Controls the method used to estimate the number of true NULL hypotheses (mo) for the adaptive methods.
arguments.help: NTRUENULL=BOOTSTRAP | DECREASESLOPE | KSTEST | LEASTSQUARES | LOWESTSLOPE | MEANDIFF | SPLINE

arguments.name: BOOTSTRAP
arguments.description: Syntax: BOOTSTRAP<(bootstrap-options)> Uses the bootstrap method of Storey and Tibshirani (2003). The available bootstrap-options are as follows: FINITE modifies the computations for the finite-sample case of the PFDR option. NBOOT=B specifies the number of bootstrap resamples of the raw p-values for the λ computations. NLAMBDA=n specifies that the "optimal" λ is the value in {0, 1/n,...,(n-1)/n} that minimizes the MSE.

arguments.name: DECREASESLOPE
arguments.description: Uses the method of Schweder and Spjøtvoll (1982) as modified by Hochberg and Benjamini (1990).

arguments.name: KSTEST
arguments.description: Syntax: KSTEST<(β)< Uses the Kolmogov-Smirnov uniformity test method of Turkheimer, Smith, and Schmidt (2001).

arguments.name: LEASTSQUARES
arguments.description: Uses a linear least squares method to search for the correct cutpoint.

arguments.name: LOWESTSLOPE
arguments.description: Uses the lowest slope method of Benjamini and Hochberg (2000).

arguments.name: MEANDIFF
arguments.description: Uses the mean of differences method of Hsueh, Chen, and Kodell (2003).

arguments.name: SPLINE
arguments.description: Syntax: SPLINE<(spline-options)> Uses the cubic spline method of Storey and Tibshirani (2003). The available spline-options are as follows: DF=df sets the degrees of freedom of the spline, where df is a nonnegative integer. The default is DF=3. DFCONV=number specifies the absolute change in spline degrees of freedom value for concluding convergence. FINITE modifies the computations for the finite-sample case of the PFDR option. MAXITER=n specifies the maximum number of golden-search iterations used to find a spline with DF= degrees of freedom. NLAMBDA=n By default, NLAMBDA=20; number must be an integer greater than 1. SPCONV=number specifies the absolute change in smoothing parameter value for concluding convergence of the spline.

arguments.name: ORDER=
arguments.description: Specifies the sorting order for the levels of the CLASS variable.

arguments.name: DATA
arguments.description: Orders values according to their order in the input data set.

arguments.name: FORMATTED
arguments.description: Orders values by their ascending formatted values. This order depends on your operating environment.

arguments.name: FREQ
arguments.description: Orders values by descending frequency count so that levels with the most observations are listed first.

arguments.name: INTERNAL
arguments.description: Orders values by their unformatted values, which yields the same order as PROC SORT. This order depends on your operating environment.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: Names the output SAS data set containing variable names, contrast names, intermediate calculations, and all associated p-values.

arguments.name: OUTPERM=
arguments.description: Names the output SAS data set containing entire permutation distributions (upper-tail probabilities) for all tests when the PERMUTATION= option is specified.

arguments.name: OUTSAMP=
arguments.description: Names the output SAS data set containing information from the resampled data sets when resampling is performed.

arguments.name: PDATA=
arguments.description: Is an alias for the INPVALUES= option.

arguments.name: PERMUTATION
arguments.description: Computes adjusted p-values in identical fashion as the BOOTSTRAP option, with the exception that PROC MULTTEST resamples without replacement rather than with replacement.

arguments.name: PFDR
arguments.description: Computes the "q-values". PROC MULTTEST treats these "q-values" as adjusted p-values.

arguments.name: PLOTS=
arguments.description: Controls the plots produced through ODS Graphics. Syntax: (1) PLOTS<(global-plot-options)>=plot-request<(options)> (2) PLOTS<(global-plot-options)>=(plot-request<(options)>< plot-request<(options)>> ) The following global-plot-options are available: UNPACKPANELS | UNPACK suppresses paneling.
arguments.help: PLOTS=ADJUSTED | ALL | LAMBDA | MANHATTAN | NONE | PBYTEST | RAWPROB

arguments.name: ADJUSTED
arguments.description: Syntax: ADJUSTED<(UNPACK)> Displays a 22 panel of adjusted p-value plots similar to those Storey and Tibshirani (2003) developed for use with the PFDR p-value adjustment method. The UNPACK option unpanels the display.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Produces all appropriate plots.

arguments.name: LAMBDA
arguments.description: Displays plots of the MSE and the estimated number of true nulls against the λ parameter when the NTRUENULL=SPLINE or NTRUENULL=BOOTSTRAP option is in effect.

arguments.name: MANHATTAN
arguments.description: Syntax: MANHATTAN<(options)> Displays the Manhattan plot (a plot of -log10 of the adjusted p-values versus the tests). You can specify the following options: GROUP=variable specifies a variable to group the adjusted p-values in the display. LABEL <=OBS> labels the observations that have adjusted p-values that are less than the value specified in the VREF= option. By default, labels are created as follows: if an INPVALUES= data set and an ID statement are specified, then the observations are labeled with the ID values; if a DATA= data set is specified, then the observations are labeled with their constructed test name; otherwise, the observation or test number is displayed. NOTESTNAME displays the number of the test instead of the test name on the X-axis, which is useful when you have many tests. UNPACK suppresses paneling. By default, Manhattan plots are created for each requested p-value adjustment, and the results are grouped in a single display, called a panel. Specify UNPACK to display each plot separately. VREF=number | NONE displays a reference line at –log10(number). The number must be between 0 and 1. By default, a reference line at –log10(0.05) is displayed; it can be suppressed by specifying VREF=0 or VREF=NONE.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Suppresses all plots.

arguments.name: PBYTEST
arguments.description: Syntax: PBYTEST<(options)> Displays the adjusted p-values for each test. The available options are as follows: NOTESTNAME displays the number of the test instead of the test name on the axis, which is useful when you have many tests. VREF=number-list displays reference lines at the p-values specified in the number-list. The values in the number-list must be between 0 and 1;

arguments.name: RAWPROB
arguments.description: Syntax: RAWPROB<(UNPACK)> Displays a uniform probability plot of 1 minus the raw p-values (Schweder and Spjøtvoll; 1982) along with a histogram. The UNPACK option unpanels the display.

arguments.name: PTRUENULL=
arguments.description: Is alias for the NTRUENULL= option, except that you can specify the proportion of true null hypotheses as a value between 0 and 1, instead of specifying the number of true null hypotheses. The available keywords are also the NTRUENULL= options.
arguments.help: PTRUENULL=BOOTSTRAP | DECREASESLOPE | KSTEST | LEASTSQUARES | LOWESTSLOPE | MEANDIFF | SPLINE

arguments.name: BOOTSTRAP
arguments.description: Syntax: BOOTSTRAP<(bootstrap-options)> Uses the bootstrap method of Storey and Tibshirani (2003). The available bootstrap-options are as follows: FINITE modifies the computations for the finite-sample case of the PFDR option. NBOOT=B specifies the number of bootstrap resamples of the raw p-values for the λ computations. NLAMBDA=n specifies that the "optimal" λ is the value in {0, 1/n,...,(n-1)/n} that minimizes the MSE.

arguments.name: DECREASESLOPE
arguments.description: Uses the method of Schweder and Spjøtvoll (1982) as modified by Hochberg and Benjamini (1990).

arguments.name: KSTEST
arguments.description: Syntax: KSTEST<(β)< Uses the Kolmogov-Smirnov uniformity test method of Turkheimer, Smith, and Schmidt (2001).

arguments.name: LEASTSQUARES
arguments.description: Uses a linear least squares method to search for the correct cutpoint.

arguments.name: LOWESTSLOPE
arguments.description: Uses the lowest slope method of Benjamini and Hochberg (2000).

arguments.name: MEANDIFF
arguments.description: Uses the mean of differences method of Hsueh, Chen, and Kodell (2003).

arguments.name: SPLINE
arguments.description: Syntax: SPLINE<(spline-options)> Uses the cubic spline method of Storey and Tibshirani (2003). The available spline-options are as follows: DF=df sets the degrees of freedom of the spline, where df is a nonnegative integer. The default is DF=3. DFCONV=number specifies the absolute change in spline degrees of freedom value for concluding convergence. FINITE modifies the computations for the finite-sample case of the PFDR option. MAXITER=n specifies the maximum number of golden-search iterations used to find a spline with DF= degrees of freedom. NLAMBDA=n By default, NLAMBDA=20; number must be an integer greater than 1. SPCONV=number specifies the absolute change in smoothing parameter value for concluding convergence of the spline.

arguments.name: RANUNI
arguments.description: Requests the random number generator used in releases prior to SAS 9.2.

arguments.name: SEED=
arguments.description: Specifies the initial seed for the random number generator used for resampling. The value for number must be an integer.

arguments.name: SIDAK
arguments.description: Computes the Šidák adjustment for each test.

arguments.name: STEPBON
arguments.description: Requests adjusted p-values by using the step-down Bonferroni method of Holm (1979).

arguments.name: STEPBOOT
arguments.description: Requests that adjusted p-values be computed by using bootstrap resampling as described under the BOOTSTRAP option, but in step-down fashion.

arguments.name: STEPPERM
arguments.description: Requests that adjusted p-values be computed by using permutation resampling as described under the PERMUTATION option, but in step-down fashion.

arguments.name: STEPSID
arguments.description: Requests adjusted p-values by using the Šidák method as described in the SIDAK option, but in step-down fashion.

arguments.name: STOUFFER
arguments.description: Requests adjusted p-values by using the Stouffer-Liptak combination method. This option is new under SAS 9.3.

statements.name: BY
statements.description: Obtains separate analyses on observations in groups defined by the BY variables.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: Specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.

arguments.name: NOTSORTED
arguments.description: Specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order.

statements.name: CLASS
statements.description: The CLASS statement is required unless the INPVALUES= option is specified. The CLASS statement specifies a single variable (character or numeric) used to identify the groups for the analysis.

arguments.name: TRUNCATE
arguments.description: Specifies that class levels should be determined by using no more than the first 16 characters of the formatted values of CLASS variables.

statements.name: CONTRAST
statements.description: This statement is used to identify tests between the levels of the CLASS variable; in particular, it is used to specify the coefficients for the trend tests.

statements.name: FREQ
statements.description: The FREQ statement names a variable that provides frequencies for each observation in the DATA= data set. Specifically, if n is the value of the FREQ variable for a given observation, then that observation is used n times.

statements.name: ID
statements.description: The ID statement names one or more variables for identifying observations in the output and in the plots. The statement requires an INPVALUES= data set. All ID variables are displayed in the “pValues” table. The ID variables are used as the X axis for the plots requested by the PLOTS=PBYTEST and PLOTS=MANHATTAN options in the PROC MULTTEST statement; they are also used to label points on the Manhattan plots. This option has no effect on the OUT= data set.

statements.name: STRATA
statements.description: The STRATA statement identifies a single variable to use as a stratification variable in the analysis.

arguments.name: WEIGHT=
arguments.description: Specifies the type of strata weighting to use when computing the Freeman-Tukey and t tests.

arguments.name: SAMPLESIZE
arguments.description: Requests weights proportional to the within-stratum sample sizes, and is the default method.

arguments.name: HARMONIC
arguments.description: Sets up weights equal to the harmonic mean of the nonmissing within-stratum CLASS sizes, and is similar to a Type 2 analysis in PROC GLM.

arguments.name: EQUAL
arguments.description: Specifies equal weights, and is similar to a Type 3 analysis in PROC GLM.

statements.name: TEST
statements.description: The TEST statement is required unless the INPVALUES= option is specified. The TEST statement identifies statistical tests to be performed and the discrete and continuous variables to be tested.

arguments.name: CA
arguments.description: Requests the Cochran-Armitage linear trend tests for group comparisons. The test variables should take the value 0 for a failure and 1 for a success. PERMUTATION= option can be used to request an exact permutation test; otherwise, a Z-score approximation is used. The CONTINUITY= option can be used to specify a continuity correction for the -score approximation.

arguments.name: FISHER
arguments.description: Requests Fisher exact tests for comparing two treatment groups. The test variables should take the value 0 for a failure and 1 for a success.

arguments.name: FT
arguments.description: Requests Z-score CA tests based upon the Freeman-Tukey double arcsine transformation of the frequencies. The test variables should take the value 0 for a failure and 1 for a success.

arguments.name: MEAN
arguments.description: Requests the t test for the mean. The test variables can take on any numeric values.

arguments.name: PETO
arguments.description: Requests the Peto mortality-prevalence test. The test variables should take the value 0 for a nonoccurrence, 1 for an incidental occurrence, and 2 for a fatal occurrence. The TIME= option should be used with the Peto test to specify an integer-valued variable giving the age at death. The CONTINUITY= option can be used to specify a continuity correction for the test.

arguments.name: BINOMIAL
arguments.description: Uses the binomial variance estimate for CA and Peto tests in their asymptotic normal approximations. The default is to use the hypergeometric variance.

arguments.name: CONTINUITY=
arguments.description: Specifies number as a particular continuity correction for the Z-score approximation in the CA and Peto tests. The default is 0.

arguments.name: DDFM=
arguments.description: Specifies whether the MEAN test uses a homogeneity assumption (DDFM=POOLED, the default) or deals with heterogeneous variances (DDFM=SATTERTHWAITE).

arguments.name: POOLED
arguments.description: Specifies that the MEAN test uses a homogeneity assumption.

arguments.name: SATTERTHWAITE
arguments.description: Specifies that the MEAN test deals with heterogeneous variances.

arguments.name: LOWERTAILED
arguments.description: Is used to make all tests lower-tailed. All tests are two-tailed by default.

arguments.name: PERMUTATION=
arguments.description: Computes p-values for the CA and Peto tests by using exact permutation distributions when marginal success or failure totals within a stratum are number or less.

arguments.name: TIME=
arguments.description: Identifies the Peto test variable containing the age at death, which must be integer valued. If the TIME= option is omitted, all ages are assumed to equal 1.

arguments.name: UPPERTAILED
arguments.description: Is used to make all tests upper-tailed. All tests are two-tailed by default.
